context/3: Pray for him, for all of them
context/4: I won´t be able to sleep tonight.
context/7: This one´s to death.

response: Maybe you do need a man around here.
context/0: Cos you're sure gonna need it.
context/1: I sure wish you troopers luck.
context/2: Get your things inside the mission.
context/3: Now, get those horses unhitched and put them in the corral.

response: Let me get down!
context/1: Let me get down, will ya?
context/3: All I want is to get outta here!
context/7: What are you gonna do to me?

context: We annihilated the world before your very ears and utterly destroyed the Columbia Broadcasting System.
response: Now, you will be relieved, I hope, to learn that we didn't mean it and that both institutions are still open for business.
context/0: Starting now, we couldn't soap all your windows and steal all your garden gates by tomorrow night, so we did the next best thing.
context/2: The Mercury Theatre's own radio version of dressing up in a sheet and jumping out of a bush and saying, boo!
context/3: This is your host, ladies and gentlemen, out of character to assure you that "The War Of The Worlds" has no further significance than as the holiday offering it was intended to be.
context/6: It oughtta be on every station in the world.
context/7: Well, I don't get it.
context/8: We haven't heard anything about it.
context/9: Well, we've been listening to the radio ever since y6ou left.

response: This is Mr. Davenport's secretary, Miss Rita Norge.
context/3: Taking charge of Edward Davenport's affairs for his widow.
context/6: My name is Mason and I'm an attorney.
context/7: Who are you?

context: Did you know him at all well?
response: Lived next door to him for five years now.
context/0: Say, what kind of a chap was he?
context/1: Me and the missus was in the back, you see, having our tea.
context/3: Nothing at all, eh?
context/6: Did you hear him come home or go into his house?
context/7: Well, you didn't hear anything at all in here?
context/9: You know, not like it ought to be.
